M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Now comes the Plaintiff, Sarah Johnson, and, pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, M.G.L. c. 209, § 36, and relevant case law, respectfully states as follows:

M.G.L. c. 209, \u00a7 36.proposition: Now comes the Plaintiff, Sarah Johnson, and, pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, M.G.L. c. 209, § 36, and relevant case law, respectfully states as follows:

Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 469 Mass. 690 (2.proposition: This Complaint for Modification is filed by Sarah Johnson, the Plaintiff, pro se, and raises issues relevant to Massachusetts case law under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and M.G.L. c. 209, § 36, among others, including the following cases for support:
Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 469 Mass. 690 (2.support_reasoning: The proposition merely states that the pro se Complaint for Modification raises issues under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209, § 36 and cites this case “for support,” but Bower v. Bournay‑Bower does not address G.L. c. 209, § 36 at all and only mentions G.L. c. 208, § 28 in the narrow context of criticizing an improper delegation of modification authority to a parenting coordinator. The holding is about inherent judicial authority and unlawful delegation, not about how to plead or frame a complaint for modification or about c. 209, § 36. Thus the opinion does not substantively support the broad proposition claimed.
Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 469 Mass. 690 (2.relevant_excerpt: “By statute, if a party seeks a modification of a final judgment of divorce, a judge may make a judgment modifying his or her earlier judgment provided the judge finds that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28. … Thus, the order is unlawful because it empowers the parent coordinator to make alterations to the parties’ custody and visitation arrangements without regard to statutory criteria governing such changes.”

Robbins v. Robbins, 411 Mass. 878 (1992).proposition: This Complaint for Modification is filed by Sarah Johnson, the Plaintiff, pro se, and raises issues relevant to Massachusetts case law under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and M.G.L. c. 209, § 36, among others, including the following cases for support:

Ross v. Ross, 385 Mass. 30 (1982).proposition: This Complaint for Modification is filed by Sarah Johnson, the Plaintiff, pro se, and raises issues relevant to Massachusetts case law under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and M.G.L. c. 209, § 36, among others, including the following cases for support:
Ross v. Ross, 385 Mass. 30 (1982).support_reasoning: The proposition merely asserts that the pro se Complaint for Modification raises issues under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and c. 209, § 36 and cites Ross v. Ross among other cases “for support.” Ross does involve Massachusetts divorce law and G.L. c. 208, § 34, but it does not interpret or apply § 28 or c. 209, § 36, nor does it speak to a pro se party’s filing of a complaint for modification. Thus, this case does not provide direct authority for the specific statutory grounds referenced in the proposition.
Ross v. Ross, 385 Mass. 30 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “Having held that the probate judge did not err in granting the wife relief from the original divorce judgment, we turn to whether G. L. c. 208, § 34, was properly applied to this case.… General Laws c. 208, § 34, empowers the courts to make an equitable division of property incident to a divorce proceeding.”

Albano v. Albano, 437 Mass. 304 (2002).proposition: This Complaint for Modification is filed by Sarah Johnson, the Plaintiff, pro se, and raises issues relevant to Massachusetts case law under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and M.G.L. c. 209, § 36, among others, including the following cases for support:
Albano v. Albano, 437 Mass. 304 (2002).case_name: Cormier v. Pezrow New England, Inc.
Albano v. Albano, 437 Mass. 304 (2002).support_reasoning: The proposition claims the case is relevant to a Complaint for Modification involving Massachusetts domestic relations statutes (M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and c. 209, § 36). The quoted opinion, however, is an employment discrimination/venue and damages decision under G.L. c. 151B, dealing with age discrimination, venue, and multiple damages. It does not concern divorce, child support, spousal support, or modification proceedings, and therefore does not support the stated proposition.
Albano v. Albano, 437 Mass. 304 (2002).relevant_excerpt: "One of the principal purposes of G. L. c. 151B is to ‘protect the citizens of the Commonwealth against employment discrimination’... The statute contains a special venue provision directing that actions for discrimination are to be brought ‘in the superior or probate court for the county in which the alleged unlawful practice occurred.’ G. L. c. 151B, § 9. We have not had occasion to interpret the words ‘in which the alleged unlawful practice occurred’..."

Sholar v. Sholar, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 73 (.raw_text: Sholar v. Sholar, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 73 (1988)
Sholar v. Sholar, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 73 (.proposition: This Complaint for Modification is filed by Sarah Johnson, the Plaintiff, pro se, and raises issues relevant to Massachusetts case law under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and M.G.L. c. 209, § 36, among others, including the following cases for support:
Sholar v. Sholar, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 73 (.support_reasoning: The proposition claims the case is relevant to a Massachusetts Complaint for Modification under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and c. 209, § 36 (domestic relations/statutory modification of support/custody). The cited opinion is a criminal appeal concerning armed burglary, robbery, evidentiary rulings, identification procedures, reasonable doubt instructions, and a motion for new trial. It does not address divorce, separation, support, custody, or any aspect of c. 208 or c. 209, and therefore does not support the proposition for which it is cited.
Sholar v. Sholar, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 73 (.relevant_excerpt: “On February 14, 1985, a Norfolk County Superior Court jury convicted the defendant of armed burglary, armed robbery, and breaking and entering in the nighttime and larceny. … The defendant raises four contentions: 1) he claims that the court erred in denying his motion to suppress identifications… 2) he contends it was error to permit a police officer to testify… 3) he argues that the judge committed reversible error in using the jury instructions… and 4) he claims error in the denial of his motion for a new trial based on newly discovered evidence.”

Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).proposition: This Complaint for Modification is filed by Sarah Johnson, the Plaintiff, pro se, and raises issues relevant to Massachusetts case law under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and M.G.L. c. 209, § 36, among others, including the following cases for support:
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).support_reasoning: The proposition only states that the pro se plaintiff’s Complaint for Modification "raises issues relevant to Massachusetts case law under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and M.G.L. c. 209, § 36, among others, including the following cases for support," and then lists Felton. Felton v. Felton is a visitation/modification case that discusses standards for modifying a divorce judgment and the need to show material change and specific harm, but it does not interpret or apply M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 or c. 209, § 36. Thus, while Felton is generally relevant Massachusetts family-law authority, it does not specifically support the statutory reference claimed in the proposition.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).relevant_excerpt: We apply the words of Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368 (1981), a case seeking modification of alimony and child support provisions in a divorce judgment, to the present case, also demanding modification of a divorce judgment, although as to a different subject matter: "To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment."

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: This Complaint for Modification is filed by Sarah Johnson, the Plaintiff, pro se, and raises issues relevant to Massachusetts case law under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and M.G.L. c. 209, § 36, among others, including the following cases for support:
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The proposition merely states that the plaintiff’s complaint for modification "raises issues relevant to Massachusetts case law under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and M.G.L. c. 209, § 36, among others, including the following cases for support," and then lists this custody case. Custody of Vaughn is a probate and family court custody decision focused on domestic violence findings, joint/shared custody, and G.L. c. 208, § 31 and c. 209A, not on modification standards under c. 208, § 28 or c. 209, § 36. While it is generally relevant to Massachusetts custody law and domestic-violence considerations, it does not provide authority interpreting or applying §§ 28 or 36, so it does not substantively support the specific statutory proposition claimed.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “The Legislature reached a similar conclusion in respect to shared legal or physical custody. General Laws c. 208, § 31, provides that ‘[i]f, despite the prior or current issuance of a restraining order against one parent pursuant to chapter two hundred and nine A, the court orders shared legal or physical custody … the court shall provide written findings to support such shared custody order.’ A G. L. c. 209A order was outstanding in this case, and the judge made no explicit findings regarding the effect of shared custody on the child.”

Anzalone v. Anzalone, 68 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Anzalone v. Anzalone, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 793 (2007)
Anzalone v. Anzalone, 68 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: This Complaint for Modification is filed by Sarah Johnson, the Plaintiff, pro se, and raises issues relevant to Massachusetts case law under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and M.G.L. c. 209, § 36, among others, including the following cases for support:
Anzalone v. Anzalone, 68 Mass. App. Ct..case_name: Statewide Towing Ass'n v. City of Lowell
Anzalone v. Anzalone, 68 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The proposition claims that Anzalone v. Anzalone is relevant authority for a pro se Complaint for Modification under Massachusetts domestic relations statutes (M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and c. 209, § 36). The provided opinion, however, is Statewide Towing Association, Inc. v. City of Lowell, a municipal/administrative law and standing case involving towing contracts, G.L. c. 159B, and G.L. c. 40, § 53—not Anzalone and not family-law modification standards. It therefore does not support any proposition about modification of divorce or support orders under those statutes and appears to be a miscitation or erroneous insertion.
Anzalone v. Anzalone, 68 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff, Statewide Towing Association, Inc. (Statewide), filed a complaint against the city of Lowell (city) and certain towing companies, seeking a declaratory judgment… Count I alleges that the towing contracts … are void because they violate G. L. c. 159B, §§ 6A and 19… Count II alleges that a provision in the contracts constitutes an impermissible tax on vehicle owners… As we conclude that Statewide lacks standing to pursue relief for counts I and II, we affirm the judgment.”

Bush v. Bush, 402 Mass. 406 (1988).proposition: This Complaint for Modification is filed by Sarah Johnson, the Plaintiff, pro se, and raises issues relevant to Massachusetts case law under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and M.G.L. c. 209, § 36, among others, including the following cases for support:
Bush v. Bush, 402 Mass. 406 (1988).support_reasoning: The proposition is very general: that a pro se Complaint for Modification raises issues under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and c. 209, § 36, "among others," and cites Bush v. Bush as one of several supporting cases. Bush squarely involves a post‑divorce complaint for modification concerning child-related provisions and alimony, and it interprets and applies G.L. c. 208, § 28 (and § 37), including the standard of "material and substantial change" for modification. While the opinion does not mention c. 209, § 36, it is relevant Massachusetts authority on modification under c. 208, § 28, so it generally supports the broad proposition that such a complaint raises issues governed by that statute and related case law.
Bush v. Bush, 402 Mass. 406 (1988).relevant_excerpt: Assuming (without deciding) that the probate judge has the authority to order that the equity in the marital home be applied to the care and maintenance of minor children under G. L. c. 208, § 28, the plaintiff has failed to demonstrate that modification of the original judgment is warranted at this time. The statute specifically provides that, "[u]pon a complaint after a divorce, ... the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care, custody and maintenance of the minor children ... provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children" (emphasis added).

Prenaveau v. Prenaveau, 23 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Prenaveau v. Prenaveau, 23 Mass. App. Ct. 228 (1986)
Prenaveau v. Prenaveau, 23 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: This Complaint for Modification is filed by Sarah Johnson, the Plaintiff, pro se, and raises issues relevant to Massachusetts case law under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and M.G.L. c. 209, § 36, among others, including the following cases for support:
Prenaveau v. Prenaveau, 23 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The proposition describes a pro se Complaint for Modification involving issues under Massachusetts domestic relations statutes (M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and c. 209, § 36). Prenaveau v. Prenaveau, however, is not a domestic relations or modification case under those statutes; it is a will contest/undue influence case concerning probate of a decedent’s will. The opinion does not interpret or apply c. 208, § 28 or c. 209, § 36, so it provides no authority relevant to that proposition.
Prenaveau v. Prenaveau, 23 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “This is an appeal by Julie Heinrich from a decision disallowing her petition for probate of an instrument purporting to be the will of Ernest W. Silvernail (decedent). … The judge made the following rulings with respect to the validity of the will: ‘The dispositive portions of the will … were procured by the undue influence exerted by the main beneficiary under the will.’ … We conclude that it has not been shown that Heinrich used her position of confidence to coerce the decedent into leaving her his property.”
